p: Hydroxychavicol or 4-allylpyrocatechol isolated from betel leaves was also reported to be effective against various fungi species. The compound could entirely kill C. albicans at a minimum concentration (400 μg/mL) [ 35]. The killing ability of hydroxychavicol against C. albicans and C. glabrata was dose-dependent. Hydrochavicol demonstrated fungicidal effects against other clinical isolates fungi, with the MICs ranging from 7.81 to 62.5 μg/mL for dermatophytes, 15.62 to 500 μg/mL for yeasts, and 125 to 500 μg/mL for Aspergillus species, while the MFCs were found to be equal or two-fold higher than the MICs [ 38]. Moreover, it could prevent biofilm formation and promote biofilm eradication [ 35, 38]. The development of a biofilm, which is a network of microbial cells tightly adsorbed at the mucosal surface, is linked to a severe infection [ 46].
